Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, we’re all counting on you to be there this weekend. It won’t be the same without you.” My family had planned a big holiday celebration, something we hadn’t done in years. As a brother, I knew how much it meant to them, especially to my parents who rarely asked for anything. But as I sat at my desk, blueprints and safety checklists spread out before me, my mind raced with the new engineering standard that had just been released. The deadline for compliance was tight, and my team was relying on me to ensure everything was up to code before the product launch. If I missed something, it could mean a costly delay or worse, a safety risk. The weight of both worlds pressed on me—my family’s expectation for togetherness, and my professional duty to uphold safety and standards. My heart ached with the thought of disappointing either side, and I found myself frozen, torn between the warmth of home and the gravity of my responsibility.
